explanation: When $x$ is closer to $0$ (e.g., $\pm 0.001$), $f(x)$ is much larger (1000) than when $x$ is farther (e.g., $\pm 0.1$ gives 10). The values increase without bound as $x\to 0$, so $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)=\infty$.

micro_explanations.A: Unbounded growth both sides.
micro_explanations.B: Wrong sign.
micro_explanations.C: Opposite trend.
micro_explanations.D: Infinite limit is a valid description here.

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces recognizing infinite limits from numerical data.
Targets the DNE vs $\\infty$ misconception.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX.
title: 1.4-P3

prompt: A function $f$ is defined near $x=2$. Use the table to estimate $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 2}\frac{f(x)-f(2)}{x-2}.$$  $$ \begin{array}{c|cccccc} x & 1.9 & 1.99 & 1.999 & 2.001 & 2.01 & 2.1\\\\ \hline f(x) & 4.61 & 4.9601 & 4.996001 & 5.004001 & 5.0401 & 5.41 \end{array} $$  Assume $f(2)=5$.

options.explanation: The quotient is not near $0$; the changes in $f(x)$ relative to changes in $x$ suggest a slope near $4$.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Left and right quotients both approach about $4$, indicating the limit exists.
$5$ is $f(2)$, but the expression is about the rate of change (slope), not the function value.

explanation: Compute the difference quotient near $2$. From the right: $\frac{5.004001-5}{0}.001\approx 4.001$. From the left: $\frac{4.996001-5}{-0.001}\approx 3.999$. Both sides approach $4$, so the limit is approximately $4$.

micro_explanations.A: Slope is not near $0$.
micro_explanations.B: Trends show existence.
micro_explanations.C: Confuses value with slope.
micro_explanations.D: Both sides approach $4$.

recommendation_reasons: Connects tabular estimation with the key limit form for instantaneous rate of change.
Trains correct setup using $f(2)$ and $(x-2)$.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX. This stays within 1.4 by estimating a limit from a table.
title: 1.4-P4

prompt: Use the table to determine $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$.  $$ \begin{array}{c|cccccc} x & -0.1 & -0.01 & -0.001 & 0.001 & 0.01 & 0.1\\\\ \hline f(x) & 1 & -1 & 1 & -1 & 1 & -1 \end{array} $$

options.explanation: Averaging the two values is not justified; the function values do not trend toward $0$.
Values near $0$ are sometimes $1$ and sometimes $-1$; there is no single value approached.
Values near $0$ are sometimes $-1$ and sometimes $1$; there is no single value approached.
The function values oscillate between $1$ and $-1$ near $0$, so they do not approach a single number.

explanation: As $x$ gets closer to $0$, the outputs keep switching between $1$ and $-1$. Since the values do not settle on a single number, $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$ does not exist.

micro_explanations.A: Averaging is not a limit rule.
micro_explanations.B: Not consistently approaching $1$.
micro_explanations.C: Not consistently approaching $-1$.
micro_explanations.D: Oscillation prevents a limit.

recommendation_reasons: Tests a high-frequency misconception: nearby values can alternate and still fail to have a limit.
Builds recognition of oscillation as a DNE pattern.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX. Designed as a discrimination item (Level 5).
title: 1.4-P5

prompt: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 3}\left(2x^2-5x+1\right).$$
latex: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 3}\left(2x^2-5x+1\right).$$

options.label: A

options.label: C

Polynomials are continuous everywhere, so the limit exists.

micro_explanations.A: Sign error.
micro_explanations.B: Arithmetic error.
micro_explanations.C: Use continuity of polynomials and substitute $x=3$.

latex: Using the graph (see image 1.5-P2.png), evaluate $$\lim_{x\to 1}\left(3f(x)-2g(x)\right).$$

options.label: A
options.explanation: From the graph, $\lim f(x)=2$ and $\lim g(x)=-1$, so $3(2)-2(-1)=8$.

options.label: B

This comes from a sign mistake when computing $-2g(x)$.
Both $\lim_{x\to 1} f(x)$ and $\lim_{x\to 1} g(x)$ exist, so the limit exists by limit laws.

explanation: From the graph, $$\lim_{x\to 1}f(x)=2,\quad \lim_{x\to 1}g(x)=-1.$$ By limit laws, $$\lim_{x\to 1}(3f(x)-2g(x))=3\cdot 2-2\cdot(-1)=8.$$

micro_explanations.A: This uses the correct limits from the graph: $f\to 2$, $g\to -1$.
micro_explanations.B: This uses incorrect graph reading for one of the limits.
micro_explanations.C: This comes from sign mistakes when computing $-2g$.
micro_explanations.D: Both $f$ and $g$ approach finite values at $x=1$, so the limit exists.

title: 1.5-P2

prompt: Suppose $$\lim_{x\to 2}f(x)=5\quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{x\to 2}g(x)=-3.$$ Evaluate $$\lim_{x\to 2}\frac{(f(x))^2}{g(x)+7}.$$
latex: Suppose $$\lim_{x\to 2}f(x)=5\quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{x\to 2}g(x)=-3.$$ Evaluate $$\lim_{x\to 2}\frac{(f(x))^2}{g(x)+7}.$$

options.explanation: This incorrectly treats $(f(x))^2$ as $2f(x)$.

options.label: B
options.explanation: The denominator limit is $-3+7=4\neq 0$, so the limit exists.
This mishandles the denominator limit $-3+7$.

explanation: By limit laws, $$\lim_{x\to 2}\frac{(f(x))^2}{g(x)+7}=\frac{(\lim f(x))^2}{\lim(g(x)+7)}=\frac{5^2}{-3+7}=\frac{25}{4}.$$

micro_explanations.A: Squaring is not doubling.
micro_explanations.B: Denominator limit is nonzero.
micro_explanations.C: Denominator limit is $4$, not $-10$.
micro_explanations.D: Compute $(5)^2$ and divide by $4$.

recommendation_reasons: Practices combining limits with powers and sums.
Targets the misconception squaring vs doubling.
notes: Focus: evaluate a composite limit using limit laws and a nonzero denominator check.
title: 1.5-P3

prompt: Evaluate (or state that it does not exist): $$\lim_{x\to 2}\frac{x+1}{x^2-4}.$$
latex: Evaluate (or state that it does not exist): $$\lim_{x\to 2}\frac{x+1}{x^2-4}.$$

options.explanation: A limit cannot be left as division by zero; you must determine the behavior.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Since the denominator approaches $0$ while the numerator approaches $3\neq 0$, the expression becomes unbounded.

options.label: C
options.explanation: This incorrectly treats $x^2-4$ as $4$ at $x=2$.
This would require the numerator to approach $0$, which it does not.

explanation: Factor $x^2-4=(x-2)(x+2)$. As $x\to 2$, the numerator $x+1\to 3$ while the denominator $(x-2)(x+2)\to 0$. A nonzero number divided by something approaching $0$ becomes unbounded, so the two-sided limit does not exist.

micro_explanations.A: A limit cannot be left as divide by zero.
micro_explanations.B: Nonzero over $0$ implies unbounded behavior.
micro_explanations.C: Denominator at $2$ is $0$, not $4$.
micro_explanations.D: Would require numerator $\to 0$.

recommendation_reasons: Builds habit of checking denominator behavior in quotient limits.
Distinguishes unbounded behavior from removable discontinuities.
notes: Focus: DNE due to infinite behavior when denominator limit is 0 and numerator limit is nonzero.
title: 1.5-P4

prompt: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to -1}\frac{x^2+3x+2}{x+2}.$$
latex: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to -1}\frac{x^2+3x+2}{x+2}.$$

options.label: A
options.explanation: Direct substitution gives $\frac{1-3+2}{1}=0$.
This comes from sign errors in $1-3+2$.
The denominator approaches $1\neq 0$, so the limit exists.

options.label: D
options.explanation: This comes from an arithmetic slip in the numerator.

explanation: Because the denominator approaches $-1+2=1\neq 0$, substitute directly: $$\lim_{x\to -1}\frac{x^2+3x+2}{x+2}=\frac{(-1)^2+3(-1)+2}{-1+2}=\frac{0}{1}=0.$$

micro_explanations.A: Denominator nonzero, so substitute directly.
micro_explanations.B: Numerator evaluates to $0$, not $1$.
micro_explanations.C: The computation shown contradicts the choice.
micro_explanations.D: This is actually the correct numeric value but not justified by a wrong reason.

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces substitution when the denominator limit is nonzero.
Targets routine arithmetic accuracy in rational expressions.
notes: Focus: direct substitution with a nonzero denominator at the limit point.
title: 1.5-P5

prompt: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 2}\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}.$$
latex: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 2}\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}.$$

options.explanation: This comes from canceling incorrectly or simplifying to $x$ instead of $x+2$.
Factor $x^2-4=(x-2)(x+2)$, cancel, then substitute to get $4$.
This results from substituting first to get $\frac{0}{0}$ and stopping.
After cancellation, the expression is continuous near $x=2$, so the limit exists.

micro_explanations.A: After canceling, you should get $x+2$, not $x$.
micro_explanations.B: Cancel the common factor then substitute.
micro_explanations.C: $0/0$ signals you must simplify first.
micro_explanations.D: Removable discontinuity implies a finite limit.

recommendation_reasons: Core technique: factor and cancel to remove $0/0$.
Targets the common mistake of substituting before simplifying.
notes: Focus: resolve an indeterminate form by factoring and cancellation.
title: 1.6-P1

prompt: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 0}\frac{\sqrt{1+x}-1}{x}.$$
latex: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 0}\frac{\sqrt{1+x}-1}{x}.$$

options.explanation: Multiply by the conjugate to simplify to $\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x}+1}$, then substitute $x=0$.
This ignores the conjugate simplification and overestimates the limit.
This comes from substituting to get $\frac{0}{0}$ and guessing.
After rationalizing, the expression is continuous at $x=0$, so the limit exists.

explanation: Rationalize: $$\frac{\sqrt{1+x}-1}{x}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{1+x}+1}{\sqrt{1+x}+1}=\frac{(1+x)-1}{x(\sqrt{1+x}+1)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x}+1}.$$ Then $$\lim_{x\to 0}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x}+1}=\frac{1}{2}.$$

micro_explanations.A: Rationalize to remove the radical in the numerator.
micro_explanations.B: You must simplify before substituting.
micro_explanations.C: $0/0$ means simplify, not guess.
micro_explanations.D: The simplified form is continuous at $x=0$.

recommendation_reasons: Canonical conjugate technique used repeatedly in AP limits.
Builds precision with algebraic manipulation before substitution.
notes: Focus: rationalize to remove radicals and resolve $0/0$.
title: 1.6-P2

prompt: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 3}\frac{x-3}{\sqrt{x}-\sqrt{3}}.$$
latex: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 3}\frac{x-3}{\sqrt{x}-\sqrt{3}}.$$

options.explanation: This misses the factor of $2\sqrt{3}$ after simplifying to $\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{3}$.
Multiply by the conjugate to cancel $x-3$, then substitute to get $2\sqrt{3}$.
This incorrectly replaces $\sqrt{3}$ with $3$ in the final step.
This is the reciprocal of the simplified expression.

explanation: Multiply by the conjugate: $$\frac{x-3}{\sqrt{x}-\sqrt{3}}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{3}}=\frac{(x-3)(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{3})}{x-3}=\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{3}.$$ Then $$\lim_{x\to 3}(\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{3})=2\sqrt{3}.$$

micro_explanations.A: You should get $\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{3}$, not $\sqrt{x}$.
micro_explanations.B: Conjugate cancels $(x-3)$ cleanly.
micro_explanations.C: Do not turn $\sqrt{3}$ into $3$.
micro_explanations.D: Not a reciprocal situation; simplify first.

recommendation_reasons: Rationalization with a difference of square roots in the denominator.
Checks symbolic precision with radicals.
notes: Focus: conjugate cancels the factor created by a difference of squares.
title: 1.6-P3

prompt: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 1}\frac{x^3-1}{x-1}.$$
latex: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to 1}\frac{x^3-1}{x-1}.$$

options.explanation: This comes from incorrect cancellation or substituting too early.
This results from factoring $x^3-1$ incorrectly.

options.label: C
options.explanation: This is a removable discontinuity, so the limit exists.

options.label: D
options.explanation: Use $x^3-1=(x-1)(x^2+x+1)$, cancel, then substitute $x=1$ to get $3$.

micro_explanations.A: After canceling you should have $x^2+x+1$.
micro_explanations.B: Difference of cubes factorization must be exact.
micro_explanations.C: Removable discontinuity implies a finite limit.
micro_explanations.D: Cancel then substitute.

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces special factoring (difference of cubes).
Extends factor-cancel technique beyond quadratics.
notes: Focus: factor using $a^3-b^3$ and cancel to evaluate the limit.
title: 1.6-P4

micro_explanations.B: This would create a jump from the approaching value shown on the graph.

micro_explanations.D: A removable discontinuity can be fixed by defining the missing point to match the limit.

latex: Use the graph of $f$ to evaluate $\lim_{x\to -1} f(x)$. [image:1.7-P1.png]

options.text: DNE because there is a hole

micro_explanations.B: $2$ is the filled point value at $x=-1$, not the limit.

micro_explanations.B: Table is slower and less exact.

prompt: For $f(x)=\dfrac{|x|}{x}$, what is $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$?
latex: For $f(x)=\dfrac{|x|}{x}$, what is $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$?

options.explanation: The expression approaches $1$ from the right and $-1$ from the left, not $0$.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Left-hand and right-hand limits are different, so the two-sided limit does not exist.
$-1$ is the left-hand limit only.

options.label: D
options.explanation: $1$ is the right-hand limit only.

explanation: Use one-sided limits: if $x>0$, $\frac{|x|}{x}=1$; if $x<0$, $\frac{|x|}{x}=-1$. Since $1\ne -1$, the limit does not exist.

micro_explanations.A: Not approaching $0$.
micro_explanations.B: Mismatch of one-sided limits.
micro_explanations.C: Only $x\to 0^-$.
micro_explanations.D: Only $x\to 0^+$.

recommendation_reasons: Strengthen automatic check of one-sided limits for absolute value/step behavior.

notes: Focus: select one-sided analysis when sign changes create different behaviors.
title: 1.7-P3

prompt: Evaluate $\lim_{x\to 2}\dfrac{1}{(x-2)^2}$.
latex: Evaluate $\lim_{x\to 2}\dfrac{1}{(x-2)^2}$.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Because $(x-2)^2>0$ and approaches $0$, the reciprocal grows without bound positively.

options.label: B
options.explanation: The denominator approaches $0$, so the expression does not approach $0$.
The square keeps the denominator positive, so it cannot go to $-\infty$.
The limit exists as an infinite limit and equals $+\infty$.

explanation: As $x\to 2$, $(x-2)^2\to 0^+$, so $\frac{1}{(x-2)^2}\to +\infty$ (vertical asymptote at $x=2$).

micro_explanations.A: Correct infinite limit.
micro_explanations.B: Reciprocal of tiny positive is huge.
micro_explanations.C: Square prevents negative values.
micro_explanations.D: Infinite limits are valid limit behavior.

recommendation_reasons: Practice choosing infinite-limit interpretation when denominator goes to $0^+$.
Avoid labeling all blow-ups as DNE without sign analysis.
notes: Focus: identify $0^+$ in denominator and conclude $+\infty$.
title: 1.7-P4

prompt: A function $h$ is defined by a graph that clearly shows a jump discontinuity at $x=a$. Which statement must be true?
latex: A function $h$ is defined by a graph that clearly shows a jump discontinuity at $x=a$. Which statement must be true?

options.label: A
options.explanation: A jump prevents the two-sided limit from matching a single value.
A jump can still have a defined value at $x=a$ (a filled point).

options.label: C
options.explanation: At a jump, the left-hand and right-hand limits are finite but unequal, so the two-sided limit does not exist.
A jump is typically finite on both sides; infinite behavior is a vertical asymptote.

explanation: A jump discontinuity means $\lim_{x\to a^-}h(x)$ and $\lim_{x\to a^+}h(x)$ exist (finite) but are not equal, so the two-sided limit does not exist.

micro_explanations.A: Continuity fails at a jump.
micro_explanations.B: Value at $a$ may be defined.
micro_explanations.C: Unequal one-sided limits.
micro_explanations.D: Infinite limits correspond to asymptotes.

recommendation_reasons: Solidify classification of discontinuities into limit exists vs limit DNE.
Reduce confusion between jump vs asymptote vs removable.
notes: Focus: jump implies unequal one-sided limits, so the two-sided limit does not exist.
title: 1.7-P5

prompt: Evaluate $\lim_{x\to 0} x^2\cos\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)$.
latex: Evaluate $\lim_{x\to 0} x^2\cos\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)$.

options.explanation: Oscillation alone does not prevent a limit when a factor forces the product to $0$.
$x^2\to 0$, so the product cannot approach $1$.

options.label: C
options.explanation: The product is between $-x^2$ and $x^2$, so it cannot approach $-1$.

options.label: D
options.explanation: Since $-1\le \cos(\frac{1}{x})\le 1$, we have $-x^2\le x^2\cos(\frac{1}{x})\le x^2$ and both bounds go to $0$.

explanation: Use $-1\le \cos(\frac{1}{x})\le 1$. Multiplying by $x^2\ge 0$ gives $-x^2\le x^2\cos(\frac{1}{x})\le x^2$. As $x\to 0$, both $\pm x^2\to 0$, so the limit is $0$.

micro_explanations.A: Squeeze can tame oscillation.
micro_explanations.B: $x^2$ kills magnitude.
micro_explanations.C: Bounds force approach to $0$.
micro_explanations.D: Correct squeeze setup.

recommendation_reasons: Rehearse standard trig bounds $-1\le\sin,\cos\le 1$ for squeeze products.
Avoid oscillates therefore DNE overgeneralization.
notes: Focus: squeeze an oscillatory factor using $[-1,1]$ bounds.
title: 1.8-P1

prompt: ["The graph shows three functions near $x=0$: $y=-|x|$, $y=x\\sin(\\frac{1}{x})$, and $y=|x|$. What is $\\lim_{x\\to 0} x\\sin(\\frac{1}{x})$? [image:1.8-P2.png]","https://xzpjlnkirboevkjzitcx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/images/mixed_content/1771629428567_1.8-P2.png"]
latex: The graph shows three functions near $x=0$: $y=-|x|$, $y=x\sin(1/x)$, and $y=|x|$. What is $\lim_{x\to 0} x\sin(1/x)$? [image:1.8-P2.png]

options.label: A
options.explanation: Because $-1\le \sin(\frac{1}{x})\le 1$, multiplying by $x$ gives $-|x|\le x\sin(\frac{1}{x})\le |x|$, and both bounds go to $0$.

options.label: B
options.explanation: The oscillation is bounded by functions that both go to $0$, so the limit exists.
The middle function stays between $-|x|$ and $|x|$, which both shrink to $0$.

options.text: The limit depends on the path to $0$
options.value: The limit depends on the path to $0$
options.explanation: This is a single-variable limit; squeeze forces a unique value.

explanation: Since $-1\le \sin(\frac{1}{x})\le 1$, we have $-|x|\le x\sin(\frac{1}{x})\le |x|$. As $x\to 0$, both $-|x|$ and $|x|$ approach $0$, so by the Squeeze Theorem the limit is $0$.

micro_explanations.A: Because $-1\le \sin(1/x)\le 1$, multiplying by $x$ gives $-|x|\le x\sin(1/x)\le |x|$, and both bounds go to $0$.
micro_explanations.B: The oscillation is bounded by functions that both go to $0$, so the limit exists.
micro_explanations.C: The middle function stays between $-|x|$ and $|x|$, which both shrink to $0$.
micro_explanations.D: This is a single-variable limit; squeeze forces a unique value.

recommendation_reasons: Connect algebraic inequalities to graphical squeezing.
Build confidence recognizing classic $x\sin(1/x)$ squeeze pattern.
notes: Focus: apply squeeze with $-|x|$ and $|x|$ as bounds.
title: 1.8-P2

prompt: ["The graph shows $g(x)=\\sin(\\frac{1}{x})$ near $x=0$. What is $\\lim_{x\\to 0} g(x)$? [image:1.8-P3.png]","https://xzpjlnkirboevkjzitcx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/images/mixed_content/1771629428989_1.8-P3.png"]

options.explanation: Although values hit $0$ infinitely often, they also hit values near $1$ and $-1$ arbitrarily close to $0$.

options.label: B
options.explanation: The function oscillates between $-1$ and $1$ without approaching a single value.
The function also takes values near $1$ arbitrarily close to $0$.

options.label: D
options.explanation: The function also takes values near $-1$ arbitrarily close to $0$.

explanation: Even though $-1\le \sin(\frac{1}{x})\le 1$, the bounds do not squeeze to a single value. Near $0$, the function attains values arbitrarily close to many numbers in $[-1,1]$, so the limit does not exist.

micro_explanations.A: Although values hit $0$ infinitely often, they also hit values near $1$ and $-1$ arbitrarily close to $0$.
micro_explanations.B: The function oscillates between $-1$ and $1$ without approaching a single value.
micro_explanations.C: The function also takes values near $1$ arbitrarily close to $0$.
micro_explanations.D: The function also takes values near $-1$ arbitrarily close to $0$.

recommendation_reasons: Differentiate bounded from squeezed.
Prevent incorrect squeeze attempts when bounds do not converge.
notes: Focus: oscillation without narrowing bounds implies the limit does not exist.
title: 1.8-P3

prompt: Suppose $|f(x)|\le 5|x-2|$ for all $x$ near $2$. What is $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$?
latex: Suppose $|f(x)|\le 5|x-2|$ for all $x$ near $2$. What is $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$?

options.label: A
options.explanation: The inequality is enough: it forces $f(x)$ to be trapped near $0$.
The inequality bounds $f(x)$ by something that goes to $0$, not by $5$.
The bounds converge to $0$, which forces existence and value $0$.

options.label: D
options.explanation: Since $-5|x-2|\le f(x)\le 5|x-2|$ and $5|x-2|\to 0$, squeeze gives $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)=0$.

explanation: Because $|f(x)|\le 5|x-2|$, we have $-5|x-2|\le f(x)\le 5|x-2|$. As $x\to 2$, both bounds go to $0$, so by Squeeze Theorem $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)=0$.

micro_explanations.A: Inequality determines it.
micro_explanations.B: Misreads inequality.
micro_explanations.C: Squeeze guarantees a limit here.
micro_explanations.D: Bounds shrink to $0$.

recommendation_reasons: Use absolute value inequalities as ready-made squeeze setups.
Practice translating $|f(x)|\le \text{small}$ into two-sided bounds.
notes: Focus: convert $|f(x)|\le C|x-a|$ into symmetric bounds that go to $0$.
title: 1.8-P4

prompt: Evaluate $\lim_{x\to 0}\dfrac{\sin^2 x}{x}$.

An indeterminate form indicates you must analyze; it may still have a limit.
Rewrite as $\left(\frac{\sin x}{x}\right)\sin x$; since $\frac{\sin x}{x}\to 1$ and $\sin x\to 0$, the product goes to $0$.
The expression is near $0$, not near $-1$.

explanation: Use the factorization $\frac{\sin^2 x}{x}=\left(\frac{\sin x}{x}\right)\sin x$. As $x\to 0$, $\frac{\sin x}{x}\to 1$ and $\sin x\to 0$, so the product tends to $0$.

micro_explanations.A: Forgets extra $\sin x$ factor.
micro_explanations.B: $0/0$ needs analysis, not surrender.
micro_explanations.C: Correct limit product.
micro_explanations.D: Not consistent with small-angle behavior.

notes: Focus: rewrite into a product with $\sin x/x$ to control the limit.

explanation: A two-sided limit exists only if the left-hand and right-hand limits are equal. Here the left-hand limit is $2$ and the right-hand limit is $-1$, so $\lim_{x\to 1} g(x)$ does not exist.

micro_explanations.B: Identify the right-hand approach value from the table trend.

prompt: Define $h(x)=\dfrac{|x-2|}{x-2}$ for $x\ne 2$. Which statement is true?

prompt: Consider $p(x)=\dfrac{x^2-9}{x-3}$ for $x\ne 3$. What must $p(3)$ be to make $p$ continuous at $x=3$?
latex: Consider $p(x)=\dfrac{x^2-9}{x-3}$ for $x\ne 3$. What must $p(3)$ be to make $p$ continuous at $x=3$?

options.explanation: Simplifying shows the limit is not $0$.
Since $\lim_{x\to 3} \dfrac{x^2-9}{x-3}=6$, defining $p(3)=6$ makes the function continuous.
This is the x-value, not the required y-value for continuity.
This is removable, so defining the point appropriately does work.

explanation: Factor $x^2-9=(x-3)(x+3)$. For $x\ne 3$, $p(x)=x+3$, so $\lim_{x\to 3} p(x)=6$. Continuity requires $p(3)=6$.

micro_explanations.A: Factor the numerator.
micro_explanations.B: Cancel $(x-3)$ for $x\ne 3$ to get the simplified form.
micro_explanations.C: Set $p(3)$ equal to the limit value.

A jump requires different left- and right-hand limits, but they are equal here.

explanation: Since $\lim_{x\to 4^-} f(x)=\lim_{x\to 4^+} f(x)=2$, the two-sided limit exists and equals $2$. Because $f(4)=7\ne 2$, the discontinuity is removable.

micro_explanations.A: Equal one-sided limits imply $\lim_{x\to 4} f(x)=2$.
micro_explanations.B: Compare $f(4)$ to the limit.
micro_explanations.C: Mismatch implies discontinuity; since the limit exists, it is removable.

prompt: Find the value of $k$ that makes $f$ continuous at $x=3$ if $f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{x^2-9}{x-3}, & x \ne 3 \\ k, & x=3 \end{cases}$

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct: for $x \ne 3$, $\frac{x^2-9}{x-3} = x+3$, so $\lim_{x\to 3} f(x) = 6$; set $k=6$.
This confuses the limit with $x^2$ evaluated at 3.

options.text: $k$ cannot be chosen to make $f$ continuous at $x=3$
options.explanation: The discontinuity is removable; choosing $k$ equal to the limit makes $f$ continuous.

options.label: D

explanation: For $x \ne 3$, factor $x^2-9 = (x-3)(x+3)$, so $f(x) = x+3$. Thus $\lim_{x\to 3} f(x) = 6$. Continuity at $x=3$ requires $f(3)=k$ to equal this limit, so $k=6$.

micro_explanations.A: Removable discontinuities can be fixed by redefining the point.
micro_explanations.B: Simplify to $x+3$ then evaluate at $x=3$.
micro_explanations.C: Limit is of $x+3$, not $x^2$.
micro_explanations.D: Do not plug into the unsimplified fraction; simplify first.

recommendation_reasons: Connects removable discontinuities to continuity via redefining a point.

notes: Removable discontinuity: set the point value equal to the two-sided limit.

micro_explanations.A: Check left limit, right limit, and the value.
micro_explanations.B: Need limit equality, not just existence of $f(0)$.

prompt: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to-\infty}\frac{-4x^4+7x^2-1}{2x^4+5x-9}.$$
latex: Evaluate the limit: $$\lim_{x\to-\infty}\frac{-4x^4+7x^2-1}{2x^4+5x-9}.$$

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct: the ratio of leading coefficients is $\frac{-4}{2}=-2$.
Equal degrees give a finite limit; the expression is not unbounded.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Equal degrees give a finite limit (ratio of leading coefficients), not an infinite limit.
This misses the negative leading coefficient in the numerator.

explanation: Divide numerator and denominator by $x^4$: $$\frac{-4+\frac{7}{x^2}\frac{-1}{x^4}}{2+\frac{5}{x^3}\frac{-9}{x^4}}.$$ As $x\to-\infty$, the terms with $1/x^k$ go to $0$, so the limit is $$\frac{-4}{2}=-2.$$

micro_explanations.A: Correct. This option aligns with the definitions and laws of limits and continuity.
micro_explanations.B: Incorrect. This option does not satisfy the requirements of limit existence or relevant theorems.
micro_explanations.C: Incorrect. This option does not satisfy the requirements of limit existence or relevant theorems.

notes: Limit at negative infinity; requires careful leading-term reasoning.

prompt: Find the end behavior of $$f(x)=\\frac{\\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}}{x}.$$ Which statement is correct?
latex: Find the end behavior of $$f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}}{x}.$$ Which statement is correct?

options.explanation: The numerator grows like $|x|$, so the ratio does not approach $0$.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Both one-sided-infinity limits exist and are finite (possibly different).
This ignores that $\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}\sim|x|$, not $x$.

options.label: D
options.explanation: Correct: $\sqrt{x^2+4x+1}\sim|x|$, so $f(x)\sim\frac{|x|}{x}$.

explanation: Factor $x^2$ inside the radical: $$f(x)=\\frac{\\sqrt{x^2(1+\\frac{4}{x}+\\frac{1}{x^2})}}{x}=\\frac{|x|}{x}\\sqrt{1+\\frac{4}{x}+\\frac{1}{x^2}}.$$ As $x\\to\\infty$, $\\frac{|x|}{x}=1$ and the radical $\\to 1$, so the limit is $1$. As $x\\to-\\infty$, $\\frac{|x|}{x}=-1$ and the radical $\\to 1$, so the limit is $-1$.

micro_explanations.A: Correct. This option aligns with the definitions and laws of limits and continuity.
micro_explanations.B: Incorrect. This option does not satisfy the requirements of limit existence or relevant theorems.
micro_explanations.C: Incorrect. This option does not satisfy the requirements of limit existence or relevant theorems.
micro_explanations.D: Incorrect. This option does not satisfy the requirements of limit existence or relevant theorems.

recommendation_reasons: Targets a common AP trap: radicals at infinity introduce $|x|$.
Builds correct two-sided end-behavior reasoning ($x\to\infty$ vs $x\to-\infty$).
notes: Advanced end behavior with radicals; distinguishes $x$ vs $|x|$.

prompt: Let $f$ be continuous on $[2,7]$ with $f(2)=-3$ and $f(7)=5$. Which statement must be true?
latex: Let $f$ be continuous on $[2,7]$ with $f(2)=-3$ and $f(7)=5$. Which statement must be true?

options.explanation: $10$ is not between $-3$ and $5$, so IVT does not guarantee it.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct: $0$ is between $-3$ and $5$, and continuity on $[2,7]$ guarantees some $c$ with $f(c)=0$.

options.label: C
options.explanation: $-4$ is not between $-3$ and $5$, so IVT does not guarantee it.
IVT does not imply monotonicity.

explanation: Because $f$ is continuous on $[2,7]$ and $0$ lies between $f(2)=-3$ and $f(7)=5$, the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees a value $c\in(2,7)$ such that $f(c)=0$.

micro_explanations.A: Correct. The Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT) states that if a continuous function takes different values at the ends of an interval, it must take all values in between.
micro_explanations.B: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].
micro_explanations.C: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].
micro_explanations.D: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces the basic IVT guarantee: continuous functions hit all intermediate $y$-values.
Targets common overclaims (values outside the endpoint range and monotonicity).
notes: IVT existence of a root via sign change across endpoints.
title: 1.16-P1

prompt: Let $f(x)=x^3-6x+1$. Use the Intermediate Value Theorem to justify that there is a solution to $f(x)=-2$ in the interval $(0,1)$. Which calculation correctly supports the conclusion?
latex: Let $f(x)=x^3-6x+1$. Use the Intermediate Value Theorem to justify that there is a solution to $f(x)=-2$ in the interval $(0,1)$. Which calculation correctly supports the conclusion?

options.text: Let $g(x)=f(x)+2$. Then $g(0)=3$ and $g(1)=-2$, so there exists $c\in(0,1)$ with $g(c)=0$, i.e., $f(c)=-2$.
options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct: $g$ is continuous and changes sign on $(0,1)$, so IVT guarantees a root of $g$, which corresponds to $f(x)=-2$.

options.text: $f(0)=1$ and $f(1)=-4$, so there is a solution to $f(x)=0$.
options.explanation: That conclusion is true, but it is not the target equation $f(x)=-2$.

options.text: $f(0)=-2$ and $f(1)=2$, so there is a solution to $f(x)=-2$.
options.explanation: These endpoint values are incorrect for this function.

options.text: $f(0)=1$ and $f(1)=-4$, so there is a solution to $f(x)=2$.
options.label: D
options.explanation: This targets the wrong value; IVT requires $-2$ to lie between the endpoint outputs.

explanation: Define $g(x)=f(x)+2$. Since $f$ is a polynomial, $g$ is continuous on $[0,1]$. Compute: $$g(0)=f(0)+2=(1)+2=3,\quad g(1)=f(1)+2=(-4)+2=-2.$$ Because $g(0)>0$ and $g(1)<0$, IVT guarantees a $c\in(0,1)$ with $g(c)=0$, so $f(c)=-2$.

micro_explanations.A: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].
micro_explanations.B: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].
micro_explanations.C: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].
micro_explanations.D: Correct. The Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT) states that if a continuous function takes different values at the ends of an interval, it must take all values in between.

recommendation_reasons: Builds correct IVT framing for equations of the form $f(x)=k$ via shifting.
Targets the common mistake of proving existence for the wrong target value.
notes: IVT setup for $f(x)=k$ using a shifted function $f(x)-k$ (or $f(x)+2$ here).

prompt: Consider $$h(x)=\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}.$$ Which statement is correct about using the Intermediate Value Theorem to guarantee a solution to $h(x)=4$ on the interval $[2,5]$?
latex: Consider $$h(x)=\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}.$$ Which statement is correct about using the Intermediate Value Theorem to guarantee a solution to $h(x)=4$ on the interval $[2,5]$?

options.text: IVT applies on $[2,5]$ because $h$ is a rational function.
options.explanation: Rational functions are not continuous where the denominator is $0$; here $x=3$ is in $[2,5]$.

options.text: IVT applies on $[2,5]$ only if $h(3)=6$ is defined.
options.label: B
options.explanation: Defining $h(3)$ would create a different function; as given, $h$ is not continuous on $[2,5]$.

options.text: IVT applies on $[2,5]$ because $h(x)=x+3$ after simplification.
options.explanation: Even though $h(x)=x+3$ for $x\ne 3$, the original function still has a discontinuity at $x=3$.

options.text: IVT does not apply on $[2,5]$ because $h$ is not continuous on $[2,5]$.
options.label: D
options.explanation: Correct: $h$ is undefined at $x=3$, which lies in the interval, so $h$ is not continuous on $[2,5]$.

explanation: IVT requires continuity on the entire closed interval. The function $$h(x)=\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}$$ is undefined at $x=3$, and $3\in[2,5]$, so $h$ is not continuous on $[2,5]$. Therefore IVT cannot be applied on that interval to guarantee a solution to $h(x)=4$.

micro_explanations.A: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].
micro_explanations.B: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].
micro_explanations.C: Correct. The Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT) states that if a continuous function takes different values at the ends of an interval, it must take all values in between.
micro_explanations.D: Incorrect. To apply IVT, the function must be continuous on the closed interval [a, b].

recommendation_reasons: Targets a high-frequency IVT mistake: canceling factors does not remove a hole from the original function.

notes: Continuity condition check for IVT on a closed interval.
